ol.li: Exponential growth was modeled by increasing functions of the form P(t)=P_0b^t, where the growth factor, b, is a number greater than 1.

assemblage.title: Exponential Growth
assemblage.p: The function P(t)=P_0 b^t describes exponential growth, where P_0=P(0) is the initial value of the function and b is the growth factor.

assemblage.title: Growth by a Constant Percent
assemblage.p: The function P(t) =P_0 (1+r)^t describes exponential growth at a constant percent rate of growth, r.
The initial value of the function is P_0 = P(0), and b=1+r is the growth factor.

assemblage.title: Compound Interest
assemblage.p: If a principal of P dollars is invested in an account that pays an interest rate r compounded annually, the balance B after t years is given by B=P(1+r)^t

ol.li: If 0 \lt b \lt 1, then P(t)=P_0b^t is a decreasing function. In this case P(t) is said to describe exponential decay.
A percent increase of r (in decimal form) corresponds to a growth factor of b=1+r. A percent decrease of corresponds to a decay factor of b=1-r.

assemblage.title: Exponential Growth and Decay
assemblage.p: The function P(t) = P_0 b^t models exponential growth and decay.

ul.li: P_0 =P(0) is the initial valueinitial value of P;
b is the growth growth factor or decay factordecay factor.

li.p: If b \gt 1, then P(t) is increasing, and b = 1 + r, where r represents percent increase.
If 0 \lt b \lt 1, then P(t) is decreasing, and b = 1 - r, where r represents percent decrease.

assemblage.title: Exponential Function
assemblage.p: An exponential function has the form f(x) = ab^x,~~~~ \text{ where } ~~~b \gt 0 ~~~\text{ and } ~~~b \ne 1 \text{, } ~~~a \ne 0

assemblage.title: Exponential Notation for Radicals
assemblage.p: For any integer n \ge 2 and for a \ge 0, a^{1/n} = \sqrt[n]{a}

ol.li: The growth factor of an exponential function is analogous to the slope of a linear function: Each measures how quickly the function is increasing (or decreasing).
Suppose L(t)=a+mt is a linear function and E(t)=ab^t is an exponential function. For each unit that t increases, m units are added to the value of L(t), whereas the value of E(t) is multiplied by b.
We do not allow the base of an exponential function to be negative, because if b \lt 0, then b^x is not a real number for some values of x.

assemblage.title: Properties of Exponential Functions, f(x) = ab^x, a \gt 0

li.p: If b \gt 1, the function is increasing and concave up;
if 0 \lt b \lt 1, the function is decreasing and concave up.
The y-intercept is (0,a). There is no x-intercept.

ol.li: The negative x-axis is a horizontal asymptote for exponential functions with b \gt 1. For exponential functions with 0 \lt b \lt 1, the positive x-axis is an asymptote.
Exponential functions are not the same as the power functions we studied earlier. Although both involve expressions with exponents, it is the location of the variable that makes the difference.

Many exponential equations can be solved by writing both sides of the equation as powers with the same base. If two equivalent powers have the same base, then their exponents must be equal also (as long as the base is not 0 or \pm 1).

assemblage.title: Definition of Logarithm
assemblage.p: For b\gt 0, b\ne 1, the base b logarithm of x,base written \log_{b} x, is the exponent to which b must be raised in order to yield x.

assemblage.title: Logarithms and Exponents: Conversion Equations
assemblage.p: If b \gt 0, b\ne 1, and x \gt 0, \blert{y = \log_b x}~~~ \text{ if and only if }~~~ \blert{ x = b^y}

assemblage.title: Some Useful Logarithms
assemblage.p: For any base b \gt 0, b\ne 1, \log_b b \amp = 1~~~ \text{ because } ~~~b^1 = b \log_b 1 \amp = 0 ~~~ \text{ because } ~~~b^0 = 1 \log_b{b^x} \amp = x~~~ \text{ because } ~~~b^x = b^x

ol.li: We use logarithms to solve exponential equations, just as we use square roots to solve quadratic equations. The operation of taking a base b logarithm is the inverse of raising the base b to a power, just as extracting square roots is the inverse of squaring a number.

assemblage.title: Steps for Solving Base 10 Exponential Equations

ol.li: Isolate the power on one side of the equation.
Rewrite the equation in logarithmic form.
Use a calculator, if necessary, to evaluate the logarithm.
Solve for the variable.

assemblage.title: Properties of Logarithms

ol.li: To solve a logarithmic equation, we first combine any expressions involving logs into a single logarithm. Then we use the conversion formula to write the equation in exponential form.
We cannot take a logarithm of a negative number or zero. Consequently, extraneous solutions can arise when we solve logarithmic equations.
Isolate the power on one side of the equation.
Take the base 10 logarithm of both sides of the equation.
Apply the third property of logarithms to simplify.
Use a calculator, if necessary, to evaluate the logarithm.
Solve for the variable.

assemblage.title: Doubling Time
assemblage.p: If D is the doubling time for an exponential function P(t), then P(t) = P_0 2^{t/D}

assemblage.title: Half-Life
assemblage.p: If H is the half-life for an exponential function Q(t), then Q(t)=Q_0 (0.5)^{t/H}
